ANZ Bank (ANZ AT)

Financials

Other News
- Japanese PM Abe is expected to win his third consecutive 3-year term as leader of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party today with votes to begin at 0500BST and results expected after 0600BST. Reports added PM Abe is seen to win 70% of the 405 parliamentarians’ votes and around 51% of the 405 votes from regional party members. (Newswires)

SOUTH KOREA

Other News

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
UK/EU

UK PM May reiterated that Chequers is the right proposal and only credible option, while she also repeated that the EU will need to evolve its position as the UK has done. PM May also ruled out a second referendum again and emphasised the UK will leave EU, while there were earlier reports that UK PM May is said to reject Barnier's Brexit proposal for the Irish border. (Newswires/Times)

UK Chancellor Hammond is confident that UK PM May will get her message across to EU leaders and confident the government will deliver a Chequers Brexit deal for Britain. (Newswires)

UK Brexit Minister Raab said we need the EU side to move in our direction in Brexit talks and it will be a lose-lose for both sides if we don’t get that movement. Raab also ruled out a second referendum and said Chequers is the only credible plan, while he also believes a deal is close and that it is a little late in the day for an alternative Brexit proposal. (Newswires)

UK Treasury Minister Mel Stride had earlier commented there could be another referendum if PM May' Chequers proposals are rejected by the commons. (Sky News)

EU's Juncker said the EU and the UK are far away from a Brexit deal, while Irish PM Varadkar also stated UK and EU are no closer to a Brexit deal than they were in March and reiterated Ireland would suffer in a no-deal scenario.  (Newswires)

German Chancellor Merkel said there will be no decisions made at the Salzburg summit and that they are slowly coming into the final phase of Brexit negotiations. (Newswires)

UK CPI YY Aug 2.7% vs. Exp. 2.4% (Prev. 2.5%). (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e -2.057M vs. Exp. -2.741M (Prev. -5.296M). (Newswires)
US EIA Weekly Gasoline Stocks w/e -1.719M vs. Exp. -0.104M (Prev. 1.25M)
 

US

US is said to drop 'buy American' demand from NAFTA negotiations, according to reports. (Newswires)

White House Advisor Hassett commented that the US is ready to move ahead with Mexico deal without Canada. Furthermore, Hassett believes US and China will reach an agreement and have lots of room to get a deal, while he also stated they are ready to give aid to US farmers if required and that the aim is to get China to stop misbehaving. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau reiterated Canada will defend its supply chains and commented that he needs to see a certain amount of movement on NAFTA. (Newswires)

US Current Account (Q2) -101.5B vs. Exp. -103.5B (Prev. -124.1B, Rev. -121.7B). (Newswires)
US Housing Starts Number Aug 1.282M vs. Exp. 1.235M (Prev. 1.168M, Rev. 1.174M)
US Building Permits Number Aug 1.229M vs. Exp. 1.31M (Prev. 1.303M)
 

MARKET RECAP

BorgWarner (BWA) was among the top performers, shrugging off PT cuts at Cowen, JPM and RBC. Praxair (PX) was higher on news that Linde (LINU GY) will sell more assets to try and salvage its merger. E*TRADE (ETFC) got a positive mention at Jefferies, and CNBC noted unusual options activity, helping the shares rise further). Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) was higher, buoyed by copper prices rising. Prudential (PRU) announced additional appointments to its board as part of its leadership succession plan. Juniper (JNPR) was upgraded at Nomura. Copart (CPRT) was hit following weak earnings, taking its place at the foot of the performer list. Valero (VLO). SPX +0.1% at 2908, NDX -0.1% at 7490, DJI +0.6% at 26401.

Bear-steepening was the theme once again, with steepening, with major curve spreads widening by between 1-3bps. As 10-year yields continue to rise, strategists have begun to question high far they will need to rise before markets react with a tantrum. There wasn’t any signs of discomfort in Wednesday’s trade, with the 10yr yield climbing to a high around 3.09%. Earlier in the week, GS said it wouldn’t be considered a meaningful sell-off until 3.05% was cleared, which could then open the door to 3.109%, the high from May. The 5-year sector was also capturing attention, with yields closing in on decade-highs. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 7+ ticks lower at 118-18.

US Market Wrap - 19 Sep 2018: Juncker says UK/EU still far away from Brexit deal
content:
To download the report, please click here. If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries lower, crude higher, dollar lower.
* REAR-VIEW: US Housing Starts miss, Building Permits beat; New Zealand GDP; ECB's Draghi (Dovish) to speak.
* AHEAD: BCB, SNB, Norges Bank, SARB, UK retail sales, Philly Fed, ECB’s Draghi, Salzburg Brexit summit.

* CHINA TRADE: Markets were calmed overnight by measured comments from Chinese president Li, who reassured that China would not engage in competitive FX devaluation, and it has ample tools to cope with difficulties. White House Advisor Hassett also comforted on this front stating he believes that the US and China will reach an agreement noting they have lots of room to get a deal; he stands ready to give aid to US farmers if required and stresses his aim is to get China stop misbehaving.

* NAFTA: White House advisor Hassett said the US is ready to move ahead with a Mexico deal without Canada. However, sources reported that a US/Canada NAFTA deal is unlikely this week. Elsewhere, Canada PM Trudeau and Foreign Minister Freeland – the latter who is back in Washington for talks with the USTR – made their familiar noises, without offering up any new info.

* BREXIT: Ahead of her meeting with EU leaders, The Times reported that UK PM May will reject EU Brexit Negotiator’s Irish backstop proposals (that Northern Ireland would effectively remain in the customs union and single market to avoid a hard border with Ireland), and describe them as unacceptable since they do not respect “the constitutional and economic integrity of the UK.” Separately, May penned an op-ed in German media calling on the EU to compromise and move towards a position that is acceptable for the UK and the EU. Separately, she gave an interview to UK press, stating that agreement with the EU was virtually done. The FT Wednesday reported that UK PM May will 'go over the head' of EU Brexit negotiator Barnier, appealing directly to EU leaders to reach a deal that does not involve detaching Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK. The approach may risk upsetting some EU leaders; Ireland Tuesday said that the UK should focus on negotiations in Brussels rather than other European capitals. On the subject of a second Brexit referendum, UK Brexit Minister Raab echoed the view of the PM in rejecting the notion. Ahead of the dinner with PM May, EU’s Juncker stated EU and UK are far away from a Brexit deal.

* GEOPOLITICS: US special envoy to Iran said that the US was seeking to negotiate a treaty with Iran that would include Tehran's ballistic missiles programme and its regional behaviour. Iran has so far rejected high level talks with the US after Trump pulled out of the nuclear deal.

* HOUSING STARTS rose by 9.2% in August and posted at 1.282mln, above the 1.235mln consensus. Wells Fargo, however, notes the gains were driven by multifamily starts, which rose by 1.9%, though noting the component is often subject therefore this strong release is unlikely to signal an improvement in homebuilding, given that affordability and supply concerns are preventing

* SPX +0.1% at 2908, NDX -0.1% at 7490, DJI +0.6% at 26401. SECTORS: Energy +0.4%, Materials +1.1%, Industrials -0.1%, Cons Discretionary +0.1%, Cons Staples -0.2%, Healthcare -0.1%, Financials +1.8%, Tech -0.1%, Telecoms -1.4%, Utilities -2.1%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: BorgWarner (BWA) was among the top performers, shrugging off PT cuts at Cowen, JPM and RBC. Praxair (PX) was higher on news that Linde (LINU GY) will sell more assets to try and salvage its merger. E*TRADE (ETFC) got a positive mention at Jefferies, and CNBC noted unusual options activity, helping the shares rise further). Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) was higher, buoyed by copper prices rising. Prudential (PRU) announced additional appointments to its board as part of its leadership succession plan. Juniper (JNPR) was upgraded at Nomura. Copart (CPRT) was hit following weak earnings, taking its place at the foot of the performer list. Valero (VLO)

* WTI (V8) SETTLES $1.27 HIGHER AT $71.12/BBL; WTI (X8) SETTLES $1.18 HIGHER AT $70.77, BRENT (X8) SETTLES $0.37 HIGHER AT $79.40/BBL. Crude was firm, with analysts at Citi citing the strength in WTI to October contract expiry on Thursday leading to some book squaring. Perhaps that is why markets shrugged off the unexpected 1.2mln barrel build in crude stocks in the week. Elsewhere, the DOE data reported Cushing stocks -1.250mln vs. exp. -2.2mln, distillates +0.839mln vs. exp. 0.651mln, gasoline -1.719mln vs. expected -0.104mln; crude production rose 0.92% to 11.00mln bbls.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLES 7+ TICKS LOWER AT 118-18 . Bear-steepening was the theme once again, with steepening, with major curve spreads widening by between 1-3bps. As 10-year yields continue to rise, strategists have begun to question high far they will need to rise before markets react with a tantrum. There wasn’t any signs of discomfort in Wednesday’s trade, with the 10yr yield climbing to a high around 3.09%. Earlier in the week, GS said it wouldn’t be considered a meaningful sell-off until 3.05% was cleared, which could then open the door to 3.109%, the high from May. The 5-year sector was also capturing attention, with yields closing in on decade-highs.

* USD: The greenback has been meandering around neutral on Wednesday, amid no new news of trade wars, a lack of speakers (FOMC meeting next week), and no A-list data on the slate. SocGen writes "the dollar rally has run out of steam somewhat and the high-beta FX sell-off likewise, yet we lack a catalyst for a meaningful reversal."

* GBP: Sterling has endured a roller-coaster session, surging above 1.32 after inflation data surprised to the upside, while the tone of commentary relating to Brexit also offers traders reasons for cautious optimism. However, it fell heavily after news that May is set to reject Barnier’s Irish backstop proposal, returning back to a 1.30 handle temporarily. The pound has stabilised around the 1.3150 level ahead of PM May’s dinner withy EU leaders. Lloyds Bank's techs are keeping an eye on the 1.3170 level, arguing that a close above it could augur a recovery back to the 1.33-1.35 region; if not, it sees support at 1.3110-1.3060 (and if those levels break, a more significant correction is possible towards channel support in the 1.2870 region, the bank says).

* EUR: Once again, despite USD weakness, the EUR is unable to build on 1.17, with today’s range between 1.1650-1.1715. Morgan Stanley says it remains bullish of European FX (SEK, NOK, GBP, EUR), and suggests keeping an eye on EURJPY, which it says could lead the rally upwards, given Italian bonds are seeing inflows: "FXhedged BTPs and volatility-adjusted BTP yields are attractive for Japanese investors," MS writes, "while first round effects are EUR-neutral, it is the tightening BTP spread, in conjunction with better EMU economic data including wages, leading to equity inflows (which are less FX-hedged) and pushing EUR front-end rates higher," adding that EURJPY breaking its 200DMA at 131.10 "is meaningful." EURJPY was straddling that 200DMA on Wednesday.

* AUD, NZD: The Aussie was buoyed by industrial metals, where copper hit a three-week high on a weaker USD and after the latest rounds of China-US tariffs undershot expectations (and China’s policymakers made calm, measured comments). That helped the AUD clear its 21DMA, and lead to some desks making the case that the AUD has built a base which could open the way for a test of the 55DMA, before eyeing 0.7360-80. With that said, some have noted that the long retail positioning could temper enthusiasm. The Kiwi shrugged-off overnight, data showing consumer confidence falling to a six-year low, and a widening current account deficit, instead takings its cue from

* NOK: Ahead of the Norges Bank's meeting on Thursday, the NOK has been trading around neutral. It is the top performing G10 FX this month, underpinned by firming oil prices and the hawkish tone out of the Norges Bank. A 25bps rate hike is expected tomorrow, however, SocGen says that USDNOK bears will also require the 2019 rate path to indicate a high probability of three rate rises next year.

* EMFX: A relative calm has set in following the latest round of trade tensions, seeing some EM FX stage a modest relief rally. Analysts at ING, however, remain cautious, and have doubts around the persistence of EM FX gains given risks of further trade war escalation ahead of the US mid-terms, as well as ongoing idiosyncratic risks (the potential US sanctions on Russia, the renewed weakening of TRY). "On the EM side, the ongoing rise in oil prices and its pro-inflationary effect is likely to keep pressure on local central banks to keep real rates attractive," the bank warns. 

* COMING-UP - BRAZIL CENTRAL BANK RATE DECISION DUE AROUND 2200 BST/1700 EST. Brazil's central bank is expected to hold the Selic rate at 6.50%, with the consensus of the view that the Copom will look through any near-term inflationary pressures due to the BRL's recent slide, as well as the trucker's strike. "Core inflation aggregates remain repressed, speaking to the degree to which the negative output gap has persisted," TD Securities writes. "The market continues to price in too little a risk that rates remain on hold for at least another 5 months, making shorter-term rates (and BRL) look attractive, though political uncertainty remains a notable risk factor." Some analysts, however, are looking for tightening at the September meeting; analysts at SocGn expect a hike, though it notes that there is risks to that forecast. "We continue to believe that BRL depreciation has meaningfully affected the inflation outlook and that things will worsen further on both the BRL and inflation front in the coming quarters," SocGen writes. "The communication will again be the key for future meetings and we expect the BCB to release a definitively hawkish statement in September, even if a rate hike is not implemented," SocGen adds.

* COMING-UP: SNB TO PUBLISH ITS RATE DECISION AND ECONOMIC PROJECTIONS AT 0830 BST/0930 CET. The central bank is expected to hold rates, and reiterate a willingness to intervene in FX; the inflation profile could be raised in 2018, 2019 could be lowered slightly. The SNB is not expected to move rates until well-after the ECB has begun its hiking cycle, analysts say. To download the report, please click here.

* COMING-UP: NORGES BANK RATE DECISION DUE 0900 BST. The Norges Bank is unanimously expected to hike interest rates by 25 bps to 0.75% at their September 20th Monetary Policy Meeting Analysts are keeping an eye out for changes to the rate path forecast that currently signals 1 hike in 2018 with 2 hikes per year flagged in 2019 and 2020. Click here to read full preview.

* COMING-UP – SARB RATE DECISION DUE FROM 1400 BST ON 20 SEPTEMBER 2018. The SARB is expected to hold rates unchanged at 6.50% at its meeting on Thursday 20th September. Given Central Banks in the EM space have recently undergone policy tightening, a hawkish SARB stance may reverse recent ZAR momentum, analysts say. Economic fundamentals have been weakening as the latest inflation release was softer than expected. Click here to read the full preview.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: whippy Wednesday for the Pound in particular
content:
GBP

Sterling is ending the midweek (EU) session relatively unchanged vs the Usd and Eur, but this does not even begin to tell half the story as the Pound was pulled from pillar to post by UK data and latest Brexit headlines. Already at multi week peaks, Cable was boosted further by above forecast headline CPI and soaked up at least some 1.3200+ offers before pulling back as longs booked profit and then retreating sharply on reports refuting claims that the EU has really softened its stance on the Irish border. However, Cable has reclaimed the 1.3100 handle since as UK Brexit Minister Raab backs up PM May’s assertion that a deal is close at hand and subsequent comments from EC President Tusk verify that several Chequers proposals are positive, but Ireland and future trade terms remain bones of contention. Eur/Gbp is currently back under 0.8900, but off lows around key chart support (100 DMA circa 0.8863).

AUD/NZD/SEK/NOK

All among the leading G10 pack, but for quite different reasons as the antipodeans extend their rebounds from recent lows on dissipating US-China trade tensions, or at least less punitive import tariffs than had been threatened at the outset of the latest set of proposed levies. Aud/Usd just off 0.7260 highs and Nzd/Usd easing back from 0.6600+ peaks, with the Kiwi now looking towards NZ GDP for some independent impetus. Turning to the Scandi crowns, and hawkish Central Bank vibes are underpinning the Sek and Nok following rhetoric from Riksbank’s Ohlsson reiterating reservations against latest repo rate guidance that pushed back hike timing, and ahead of Thursday’s Norges Bank policy meeting that is widely tipped to culminate in a 25 bp tightening and perhaps come with a steeper path for further normalisation. Eur/Sek down around 10.3600 and Eur/Nok circa 9.5100.

CHF

In stark contrast to the above, the Franc has retreated markedly ahead of tomorrow’s SNB quarterly review and a very likely underlining if not upgraded view of the Chf’s status along the various grades of words used to measure relative strength. Usd/Chf back up near 0.9700 and Eur/Chf close to 1.1300.

JPY/CAD/EUR

Narrowly mixed vs the recovering Greenback (DXY not far from 94.700 vs 94.317 at one stage), with Usd/Jpy rangy between 112.00 option expiries and 112.50 barriers, the Loonie losing momentum ahead of 1.2925 and reversing towards 1.3000 following several less positive NAFTA reports (deal unlikely this week and US ready to go ahead without Canada and sign off on a bilateral agreement with Mexico and Eur/Usd slipping a bit further below 1.1700 and not far from light stops said to be sitting at 1.1650.

subject: EU Summit Chair Donald Tusk says some Chequers proposals are positive but the UK must rework proposals on Ireland and future trade
content: • He adds he wants to finalise Brexit talks this autumn and says the Brexit summit should be in mid-November

content:
• Mobile Mini (MINI) initiated with a Buy at Berenberg; PT - USD 53 (Newswires)
  • McGrath RentCorp (MGRC) initiated with a Buy at Berenberg; PT - USD 70 (Newswires)
  • Tilray (TLRY) - Citron Research have tweeted that the recent move in the cannabis stock is beyond comprehension and are still short the co. (Newswires)
  • Virtu Financial (VIRT) initiated with a Neutral at Compass Point; PT - USD 23 (Newswires)
  • Fitbit (FIT), Humana (HUM) - The two healthcare co.s are expanding their partnership to improve healthy behaviors for the prevention and management of chronic conditions. (Newswires) 
  • Copart (CPRT) Q4 EPS USD 0.45 vs. Exp. USD 0.48, revenue Q4 USD 449.2mln vs. Exp. USD 444.17mln. (Newswires)

subject: Fixed and FX latest: divergence, block trades and some Dollar respite
content: Somewhat mixed US data, but on balance better than forecast has not really altered the landscape, but Bunds extended their relatively firm recovery to 158.87 (+13 ticks and almost ½ point off the Eurex session floor) amidst a more pronounced retreat in Italian BTPs and relative weakness/underperformance vs Gilts after significantly stronger than expected UK inflation data. Meanwhile, some decent clips have been blocked in US Treasuries and although not simultaneous the buyer of 5 year notes and subsequent seller of 10s does chime with the overall steepening dynamic. Turning to the currency markets, some paring of Usd shorts vs majors has helped the DXY rebound above 94.500 and almost to 94.700, but EMs are extending gains vs the Greenback.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 19th September 2018
content:

  • Praxair (PX) – The industrial gasses group alongside, Linde AG (LINU GY), have moved further towards their planned merger
  • AMD (AMD), Intel (INTC) – The semiconductor co. has had its price target raised to USD 28 from USD 11 by Morgan Stanley
  • Goldman Sachs (GS), Tesla (TSLA) - The SEC has also subpoenaed the bank and Silver Lake, alongside Tesla

19th September 2018

DOW JONES

  • Disney (DIS) – The entertainment co. has announced Marvel Universe heroes will receive their own TV series on its upcoming streaming service with large, competitive budgets. (Newswires)
  • Goldman Sachs (GS) - The SEC has also subpoenaed the bank and Silver Lake, alongside Tesla (TSLA), in its probe into the automaker. (Newswires)
  • JPMorgan (JPM) – The bank announced an increase in its common stock dividend to USD 0.80/shr from USD 0.56/shr. Elsewhere, the co. has been overtaken by communal office space co., WeWork, as the largest tenant of Manhattan office space. (Newswires)
  • McDonald’s (MCD) – The European Commission has said the fast-food restaurant was not involved in illegal activity in regard to the non-taxation of certain profits in Luxembourg locations. (Newswires)
  • Microsoft (MSFT) – The co. has announced the introduction of new AI and mixed reality applications for Dynamics: Dynamics 365 AI applications, Dynamics 365 Remote Assist and Dynamics 365 Layout. Elsewhere, the co. raises its quarterly dividend to USD 0.46 from USD 0.42. (Newswires)
  • Walmart (WMT) – Britain’s competition regulator has referred UK supermarket Sainsbury’s (SPRY LN) planned GBP 7.3bln acquisition of Walmart’s UK based Asda stores, citing concerns of the stores becoming the sole suppliers in certain locations and hence allowing potential higher prices and lack of quality. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • AbbVie (ABBV) – The pharma co. is being sued by an insurance regulator in California for giving “kickbacks” to providers of healthcare for the prescription of arthritis drug, Humira. (Newswires)
  • AMD (AMD), Intel (INTC) – The semiconductor co. has had its price target raised to USD 28 from USD 11 by Morgan Stanley, citing competitor Intel’s (INTC) output disruptions creating advantages for AMD. Morgan Stanley cut its Intel price target to USD 50 from USD 56. (Newswires)
  • Bank of New York Mellon (BK) – KPMG Audit Plc have admitted Misconduct under the Financial Reporting Council’s Accountancy Scheme, following its auditing of the bank. A disciplinary tribunal will decide what sanctions should be imposed. (Newswires)
  • Comcast (CMCSA) and Fox (FOXA) – The two broadcasters’ battle for the acquisition of UK broadcaster Sky (SKY LN) could be resolved in a one-day auction, according to sources. (Newswires)
  • Dover (DOV) – The industrial products group has announced a finalised contract with Hainan Huasheng New Material Technology (HHNMT). The contract is for the supply of pumps, screen changers and pelletising systems for HHNMT’s new polycarbonate-production facility in the Hainan Province, Southern China. (Newswires)
  • General Electric (GE) – GE Transport has announced at its InnoTrans 2018 that Indian Railways approved GE’s diesel-electric Evolution Series prototype locomotive. This is part of a 2015 USD 2.5bln agreement. (Newswires)
  • MGM Resorts (MGM) – Starboard Value has secretly taken a large position in MGM, with the stake said to be upwards of USD 500mln. Sources reported MGM said to have no shares or economic exposure to the co. (New York Post/Newswires)
  • Praxair (PX) – The industrial gasses group alongside, Linde AG (LINU GY), have moved further towards their planned merger after announcing the sale of additional assets to a consortium of CVC Capital Partners and Messer Group; becoming more inline with US antitrust approval. (Newswires)
  • Prudential (PRU) – The insurance provider has named Scott Sleyster as its COO and Ken Tanji as its CFO, both will become EVPs. (Newswires)
  • Target (TGT) – The retailer has announced a quarterly dividend of USD 0.64/shr. (Newswires)
  • Unum (UNM) – The Tennessee based insurance provider has selected Clearwater Analytics’ cloud-based investment solutions for more than 20 of its home-grown and third-party systems. (Newswires)  
  • US automakers (FCAU, F, GM) – The European Automotive Manufacturers Association announced that the demand for new cars in the EU grew by 10.5% in July and 31.2% in August. (Newswires)
  • US Banks, (C, CIT, BAC, GS) – Oppenheimer analyst Chris Kotowski has said US banks are in “good shape” with low risk (historically relative) balance sheets and the average bank PE ratio at approximately 66% relative to the S&P 500, his top picks include C, BAC, CIT and GS. (Newswires)
  • Wynn Resorts (WYNN) – The casino and hotel co., alongside its former CEO Steve Wynn, are being sued by Sterling Suffolk Racecourse which alleges Wynn rigged the application process for the Boston area’s only casino license; Sterling is seeking over USD 1bln in damages. (Newswires)
  • Yum! Brands (YUM) – UBS raises its price target to USD 99 from USD 91. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Amazon (AMZN) – EU’s Vestager says Amazon was probed by the EU over data collection from rival retailers. Separately, the online retailer has announced the launch of its activities in Turkey, where it is offering products across 15 categories, it says it plans to keep expanding its operations in the region. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – The social media giant is said to have been in talks with banks for the utilisation of customer’s financial data as late as last year; this comes in the wake of the Cambridge Analytica scandal and increasing concern on the co.’s data handling. (Newswires)
  • Netflix (NFLX) – The streaming co. has had its price target raised to USD 420 from USD 360 by Guggenheim analyst Michael Morris, citing greater than expected subscriber penetration. (Newswires)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – Former GM (GM) vice chairman, Bob Lutz, said the co. is headed for the “graveyard”, saying it will never make money on the model 3 as its costs are way too high. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Alibaba (BABA) – The Chinese tech giant has expanded its partnership with German software co., SAP (SAP GY), where they will offer SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Cloud Platform on Alibaba Cloud's infrastructure in China to help customers transition to the cloud. Elsewhere, the co. is said to be in plans to set up a dedicated chip subsidiary with anticipation of its own AI inference chip in the second half of 2019. (Newswires)
  • Athenahealth (ATHN) – The healthcare networks provider has had its price target lowered to USD 140 from USD 170 by Deutsche Bank, citing inconsistent media reports on the co.’s sale process and that he would not be surprised to learn interest is not as strong as management expected. (Newswires)
  • Celanese (CE) – The chemicals co. has announced it will be raising the price for acetate low in Eastern Europe and Asia by USD 1/Kg; made effective for orders from November 1st. (Newswires)
  • Jones Lang LaSalle (JLL) – The investment manager’s CFO Christie Kelly has resigned to pursue other opportunities, she will oversee a smooth transition. (Newswires)
  • Square (SQ) – The IT co.’s CFO, Sarah Friar, announced it is aiming to cultivate an omnichannel approach in the restaurant industry, it plans to leverage its up and coming food ordering subsidiary Caviar. (Newswires)
  • Tencent (TCEHY) – The Chinese conglomerate has halved the amount of capital it is looking to raise for its approaching Tencent Music IPO to USD 2bln. (Newswires)
  • Timken (TKR) – The bearings manufacturer announced the completion of its acquisition of Rollon Group, who specialise in engineered linear guides, telescopic rails and linear actuators. (Newswires)
  • Wabco (WBC) – The automotive systems co. has signed a Memorandum of Understanding with automotive tech co. Valeo for the development of sensor technologies. Elsewhere, Wabco has signed a range of agreements with: RIO, where RIO will leverage WBC’s Fleet Management Solutions for the support of the European logistics industry; with Nidec to produce electric drivetrain and brake control solutions; with Baidu (BIDU) for autonomous commercial vehicle driving solutions. (Newswires)

subject: Scotiabank FX Daily - Markets Remain in Pro-Risk Mood, GBP Choppy
content:
•   USD mostly lower on the day as markets ignore rising US yields.
  •   CAD firmer on technical momentum, ignores spreads & NAFTA for now.
  •   EUR firm but unable to push above 1.17. EZ net portfolio flows positive.
  •   GBP higher on CPI data but plunged around the open on Brexit headlines.
  •   JPY under-performs but holds key 112.60/65 area; BoJ remains on hold.
  •   AUD, NZD better supported on pro-risk sentiment. NZ Q2 GDP due tonight.
  •   MXN modestly firmer but USDMXN holding wide range around 19.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 19th September 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Trade war concerns continue to abate as European and Asian equites extend on the previous sessions gains
  • UK CPI beats expectations and upbeat Brexit commentary helps Cable improve on 8 week highs
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US Building Permits, Housing Starts, DoEs, BCB rate decision, NZ GDP and ECB’s Draghi

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded positive following the gains in the US as global markets took the well-telegraphed and lower than feared tit-for-tat tariffs between US and China in their stride. ASX 200 (+0.5%) was positive with outperformance in miners and energy names following gains in copper and crude oil, while Nikkei 225 (+1.1%) outperformed on a weaker JPY and better than expected trade data. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.1%) were initially indecisive due to the uncertainty from the escalation of trade tensions and after the PBoC slowed down on its liquidity efforts, but then shrugged off the concerns alongside the widespread gains in the region and with risk sentiment also underpinned by comments from Premier Li who noted several measures to support companies and dismissed resorting to a devaluation of the currency. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded lower amid the outperformance of Japanese stocks but with losses contained as participants were somewhat tentative heading into the BoJ which proved to be a non-event.

PBoC injected CNY 40bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 20bln via 14-day reverse repos for a net neutral position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8569 (Prev. 6.8554)

Chinese Premier Li said China will accelerate steps to opening up the economy and that unilateralism will not resolve issues. Furthermore, Li said China will not resort to forceful stimulus and will not engage in competitive weakening of the currency, nor will it devalue the currency to boost exports. Li also commented they will fine tune policy pre-emptively and will cut taxes and fees as well as ease funding difficulties for companies, while he noted that China's economy maintains steady growth and fundamentals are healthy but difficulties for maintaining growth are increasing. (Newswires)

BoJ kept all monetary policy settings unchanged as expected with NIRP held at -0.1% and 10yr JGB yield target at around 0%. The BoJ also maintained its forward guidance in which it will keep current extremely low rates for an extended period of time and maintained pledge to buy JGBs in a flexible manner so holdings rise at an annual pace of about JPY 80tln. Furthermore, the decision on YCC was made by 7-2 vote with Kataoka and Harada the dissenters as Kataoka dissented on view inflation will speed up to the 2% target and board member Harada said guidance which could clarify price target was needed. (Newswires)

Japanese Trade Balance (JPY)(Aug) -444.6B vs. Exp. -468.7B (Prev. -231.2B, Rev. -231.9B). (Newswires)
Japanese Exports (Aug) Y/Y 6.6% vs. Exp. 5.6% (Prev. 3.9%)
Japanese Imports (Aug) Y/Y 15.4% vs. Exp. 14.9% (Prev. 14.6%)

EU/UK/US

UK CPI YY Aug 2.7% vs. Exp. 2.4% (Prev. 2.5%)

UK CPI MM Aug 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.5%

UK PM May said exit deal is virtually agreed and ruled out a 2nd referendum according to UK press reports, while UK PM May stated that UK and EU are close to an orderly Brexit withdrawal agreement according to a German news article. (Express/Die Welt)

UK PM May urged EU to evolve its Brexit stance and said they can avoid a disorderly Brexit with goodwill and determination. PM May also stated neither side can demand the unacceptable such as customs border between parts of the UK, while she added that Britain is not seeking EU membership rights without the obligations and believes she is proposing a fair agreement, according to a senior Downing Street source. (Newswires)

UK PM May is reportedly to bypass EU Chief Brexit negotiator Barnier in a drive to win over EU leaders, while it is speculated that she will use the Salzburg meeting to seek a compromise solution for the Irish border. (FT)

DUP's deputy leader says Barnier's backstop comment still means a border down the Irish sea, just with different kinds of checks. (Newswires)

Italian Deputy PM Di Maio has stated that Italy are to lift their deficit/GDP ratio level to 2.5%. (Newswires)

US Senate passed stop-gap funding bill to keep the government open through early December and avert a shutdown. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

South Korean President Moon and North Korean Leader Kim signed join agreement following the conclusion of official summit discussions. North Korean Leader Kim stated they will make the Korean peninsula into a place without nuclear weapons and agreed to visit Seoul. There were also comments from South Korean President Moon that both sides have agreed to eliminate threat of war in the peninsula and agreed measures for denuclearization, while he added North Korea could dismantle Yongbyun nuclear facility and can permit international inspections of dismantlement. (Newswires)

US President Trump tweeted that North Korean Leader Kim agreed to allow nuclear inspections, subject to final negotiations, and permanently dismantle a test site in the presence of international experts, while he added North and South Korea will file joint bid to host 2032 Olympics. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

BoE's Vlieghe said UK pay growth is increasing quite slowly and several indicators suggest low unemployment is making it difficult for employers to find or retain staff. (Newcastle Chronicle)

EQUITIES

European bourses (Eurostoxx 50 +0.2%) broadly trade with modest gains thus far in the wake of what was a relatively up-beat Asia-Pac session as trade fears (temporarily) dissipated. The FTSE 100 (-0.2%) lags its peers amid the firmer GBP (post-CPI). Losses for the index have been contained by upside in mining names with materials the outperforming sector; in-fitting with price action in the complex overnight.

In terms of individual movers and shakers, Danske Bank sit at the foot of the Stoxx 600 after recent money-laundering troubles forced the co. to cut guidance and remove their CEO. Kingfisher (-5.0%) shares were dealt a blow after announcing a 15% decline in profits with markets also unimpressed by the latest update from Adecco (-4.8%) after the co. forecast a slowdown in revenue growth. To the upside, Babcock (+4.8%) leads the charge for the Stoxx 600 after sticking to their guidance, whilst Commerzbank (+2.8%) are also seen higher after a broker upgrade at RBC.

FX

GBP - Among the G10 outperformers, but off best levels on a combination of technical selling around resistance, profit taking and the realisation that 2.7% y/y UK CPI vs the 2.4% consensus will not materially change the BoE policy outlook in the near term at least. Indeed, that rests largely on Brexit developments and the kind of deal that appears to remain on course to be agreed by November. Cable spiked above 1.3200 at one stage, but ran in to heavy offers above the big figure and up to 1.3215, while Eur/Gbp retreated from 0.8900 again before testing but not clearing its 100 DMA around 0.8863 or stops below convincingly.

AUD/NZD -The antipodean Dollars continue to benefit from US-China trade relief in light of reduced tariffs on both sides and the prospect that the next set of proposed import charges may yet be avoided altogether if Washington and Beijing talk to each other before September 24. Aud/Usd is trying to extend relief gains beyond 0.7250 having overcome chart resistance around 0.7229, while the Kiwi is hovering above 0.6600 ahead of NZ GDP data that will be the next domestic focus, if not driver.

EUR/CAD - Also bid vs a broadly soft Greenback, but the single currency is still struggling to make a clean break above 1.1700 amidst reported decent offers between 1.1720-50, while the Loonie is around 1.2950 in the run up to more NAFTA talks and testing the first band of offers seen up to 1.2940.

JPY/CHF - The ‘safe-havens’ are still lagging the major field with Usd/Jpy pivoting a 112.38 Fib, but the pair holding or capped just in advance of 112.50 barrier interest, while the Franc has reversed relatively sharply from near 0.9600 peaks yesterday back below 0.9650 and under Eur/Chf pre-SNB quarterly policy review tomorrow.

EM - The revival across the region has resumed, and with the Try and Zar prominent ahead of potentially key/pivotal events on Thursday in the form of the SARB policy meeting and Turkish medium term economic plan. The Rand is back above 15.0000 vs the Usd, and firmly in spite of softer than forecast SA inflation data that should confirm no change in official rates, while the Lira has recovered from recent wobbles to trade over 6.3000 again vs the Dollar

FIXED INCOME

Only a very marginal fresh Eurex intraday high, and perhaps scant recognition of what can only be deemed a very well received 2028 Bund offering by all the usual measures used to gauge the success of a tap or new issue, bar perhaps the elevated yield, although that was part of a general ratchet up that improved its attraction. 10 year futures just traded at 158.75, +2 ticks vs -32 ticks at worst, Gilts rebounding from post-UK CPI lows to 120.86 (but notably Short Sterling still as much as 4 ticks adrift) and US Treasuries also paring losses.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent crude futures trade relatively unchanged and in close proximity to recent Saudi-inspired highs with last night’s unexpected build in the API survey providing a minimal drag on prices. Focus throughout the week will likely begin to turn towards this weekend’s meeting in Algiers which will see OPEC and OPEC+ producers take stock of their latest strategy adjustment in June with Iranian production likely a hot-topic for the event.

In metals markets, spot gold is modestly firmer alongside a slightly softer USD with the yellow metal maintaining a USD 1200/oz handle. Elsewhere, copper in Shanghai hit a one-month high overnight amid support from the broader risk-appetite, with sentiment also propelling zinc to trade with gains of circa 3%. Finally, plans for Chinese infrastructure spending helped underpin steel rebar prices with the metal posting its best daily performance in a week.

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (14 Sep) +1.249M vs. Exp. -2.700M (Prev. -8.636M). (Newswires)

Aud/Usd is trying to extend relief gains beyond 0.7250 having overcome chart resistance around 0.7229, while the Kiwi is hovering above 0.6600 ahead of NZ GDP data that will be the next domestic focus, if not driver.

EUR/CAD - Also bid vs a broadly soft Greenback, but the single currency is still struggling to make a clean break above 1.1700 amidst reported decent offers between 1.1720-50, while the Loonie is around 1.2950 in the run up to more NAFTA talks and testing the first band of offers seen up to 1.2940.

JPY/CHF - The ‘safe-havens’ are still lagging the major field with Usd/Jpy pivoting a 112.38 Fib, but the pair holding or capped just in advance of 112.50 barrier interest, while the Franc has reversed relatively sharply from near 0.9600 peaks yesterday back below 0.9650 and under Eur/Chf pre-SNB quarterly policy review tomorrow.

EM - The revival across the region has resumed, and with the Try and Zar prominent ahead of potentially key/pivotal events on Thursday in the form of the SARB policy meeting and Turkish medium term economic plan. The Rand is back above 15.0000 vs the Usd, and firmly in spite of softer than forecast SA inflation data that should confirm no change in official rates, while the Lira has recovered from recent wobbles to trade over 6.3000 again vs the Dollar

FIXED INCOME

Only a very marginal fresh Eurex intraday high, and perhaps scant recognition of what can only be deemed a very well received 2028 Bund offering by all the usual measures used to gauge the success of a tap or new issue, bar perhaps the elevated yield, although that was part of a general ratchet up that improved its attraction. 10 year futures just traded at 158.75, +2 ticks vs -32 ticks at worst, Gilts rebounding from post-UK CPI lows to 120.86 (but notably Short Sterling still as much as 4 ticks adrift) and US Treasuries also paring losses.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent crude futures trade relatively unchanged and in close proximity to recent Saudi-inspired highs with last night’s unexpected build in the API survey providing a minimal drag on prices. Focus throughout the week will likely begin to turn towards this weekend’s meeting in Algiers which will see OPEC and OPEC+ producers take stock of their latest strategy adjustment in June with Iranian production likely a hot-topic for the event.

In metals markets, spot gold is modestly firmer alongside a slightly softer USD with the yellow metal maintaining a USD 1200/oz handle. Elsewhere, copper in Shanghai hit a one-month high overnight amid support from the broader risk-appetite, with sentiment also propelling zinc to trade with gains of circa 3%. Finally, plans for Chinese infrastructure spending helped underpin steel rebar prices with the metal posting its best daily performance in a week.

Fixed Income: UK inflation beat gives bond bears more incentive
content: The headline ONS CPI data certainly lived up to its status as a top-tier release, and with a marked upside print vs the median forecast Gilts have led the latest downturn in debt futures to fresh session lows, at 120.60 (-54 ticks) and 158.42 for Bunds (-32 ticks). The latter thereby breached near term support around 158.51, and stopped just shy of 158.37, with the corresponding 10 year German benchmark yield crossed 0.5% ahead of Eur3 bn 2028 supply that could actually benefit from the indirect concession. Elsewhere, US Treasuries continue to decline and steepen in sympathy with EU equivalents having steered bonds down further overnight as the feedback loop turns full circle again.

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling futures marginally steeper pre-UK data
content: UK debt has kicked off ‘CPI day’ on the defensive, around 121.00 within a 120.89-121.13 range vs Tuesday’s 121.14 Liffe settlement and underperforming against the STIR strip that is just a tick either side of unchanged. The short end of the curve appears underpinned on benign expectations for the latest UK inflation report, while noting comments from BoE’s Vlieghe about the slow evolution of pay growth, ahead of more MPC comments via Haldane. However, Brexit deal optimism and even less safe-haven premium for US-China and global protectionism are the overarching factors/drivers for financial markets.

Bunds: braced for 0.5% 10 year yield test, and supply could seal it
content: The 10 year German benchmark remains under pressure along with US Treasuries, and after a fleeting/tame bounce from near term support around yesterday’s Eurex session low, the core Eurozone bond is now grinding lower again, to 158.60 at worst, so far (-14 ticks). In cash terms, this has nudged yields closer to 0.5% and technical resistance near the psychological level and it may well be breached ahead of upcoming supply, as market contacts flag 158.51 as the next downside chart target before a stronger level at 158.37. Aside from the general bearish trend, Bunds will also be keeping a check and taking heed of Italian budget developments with repercussions for BTPs that remain elevated above 127.00, at present.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

19th September 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded positive following the gains in the US as global markets took the well-telegraphed and lower than feared tit-for-tat tariffs between US and China in their stride. ASX 200 (+0.5%) was positive with outperformance in miners and energy names following gains in copper and crude oil, while Nikkei 225 (+1.2%) outperformed on a weaker JPY and better than expected trade data. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.0%) were initially indecisive due to the uncertainty from the escalation of trade tensions and after the PBoC slowed down on its liquidity efforts, but then shrugged off the concerns alongside the widespread gains in the region and with risk sentiment also underpinned by comments from Premier Li who noted several measures to support companies and dismissed resorting to a devaluation of the currency. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded lower amid the outperformance of Japanese stocks but with losses contained as participants were somewhat tentative heading into the BoJ which proved to be a non-event.

FTSE

Unilever (ULVR LN) – Shareholders M&G Investments have critiqued the plans to abandon the co.’s 88 year Anglo-Dutch dual governance structure. (Times)

Tesco (TSCO LN) – The co. are set to launch their own discount store format today, taking on rivals Aldi and Lidl. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Bayer (BAYN GY) – The co. has asked a Californian judge to reverse the USD 289mln glyphosate verdict, arguing that the jury’s decision was insufficiently supported by the evidence presented, and statements from groundskeeper Johnson’s lawyers inflamed and inappropriately influenced the jurors, claims which Johnson’s lawyers deny. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 19th September 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets traded firmer following the gains in the US. Chinese bourses lifted by support measures announced by Premier Li
  • In Brexit, UK PM May claims that an exit deal is virtually agreed, whilst Barnier states the EU is ready to improve its proposal on Northern Ireland
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK CPI, US Building Permits, Housing Starts, DoEs, BCB rate decision, NZ GDP, BoE’s Haldane, ECB’s Draghi and supply from Germany

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded positive following the gains in the US as global markets took the well-telegraphed and lower than feared tit-for-tat tariffs between US and China in their stride. ASX 200 (+0.5%) was positive with outperformance in miners and energy names following gains in copper and crude oil, while Nikkei 225 (+1.2%) outperformed on a weaker JPY and better than expected trade data. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.0%) were initially indecisive due to the uncertainty from the escalation of trade tensions and after the PBoC slowed down on its liquidity efforts, but then shrugged off the concerns alongside the widespread gains in the region and with risk sentiment also underpinned by comments from Premier Li who noted several measures to support companies and dismissed resorting to a devaluation of the currency. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded lower amid the outperformance of Japanese stocks but with losses contained as participants were somewhat tentative heading into the BoJ which proved to be a non-event.

PBoC injected CNY 40bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 20bln via 14-day reverse repos for a net neutral position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8569 (Prev. 6.8554)

Chinese Premier Li said China will accelerate steps to opening up the economy and that unilateralism will not resolve issues. Furthermore, Li said China will not resort to forceful stimulus and will not engage in competitive weakening of the currency, nor will it devalue the currency to boost exports. Li also commented they will fine tune policy pre-emptively and will cut taxes and fees as well as ease funding difficulties for companies, while he noted that China's economy maintains steady growth and fundamentals are healthy but difficulties for maintaining growth are increasing. (Newswires)

BoJ kept all monetary policy settings unchanged as expected with NIRP held at -0.1% and 10yr JGB yield target at around 0%. The BoJ also maintained its forward guidance in which it will keep current extremely low rates for an extended period of time and maintained pledge to buy JGBs in a flexible manner so holdings rise at an annual pace of about JPY 80tln. Furthermore, the decision on YCC was made by 7-2 vote with Kataoka and Harada the dissenters as Kataoka dissented on view inflation will speed up to the 2% target and board member Harada said guidance which could clarify price target was needed. (Newswires)

Japanese Trade Balance (JPY)(Aug) -444.6B vs. Exp. -468.7B (Prev. -231.2B, Rev. -231.9B). (Newswires)
Japanese Exports (Aug) Y/Y 6.6% vs. Exp. 5.6% (Prev. 3.9%)
Japanese Imports (Aug) Y/Y 15.4% vs. Exp. 14.9% (Prev. 14.6%)


UK/EU

UK PM May said exit deal is virtually agreed and ruled out a 2nd referendum according to UK press reports, while UK PM May stated that UK and EU are close to an orderly Brexit withdrawal agreement according to a German news article. (Express/Die Welt)

UK PM May urged EU to evolve its Brexit stance and said they can avoid a disorderly Brexit with goodwill and determination. PM May also stated neither side can demand the unacceptable such as customs border between parts of the UK, while she added that Britain is not seeking EU membership rights without the obligations and believes she is proposing a fair agreement, according to a senior Downing Street source. (Newswires)

UK PM May is reportedly to bypass EU Chief Brexit negotiator Barnier in a drive to win over EU leaders, while it is speculated that she will use the Salzburg meeting to seek a compromise solution for the Irish border. (FT)

EU's Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier said EU is ready to improve its proposal on Northern Ireland and that we are on the home stretch in Brexit talks but stopped short of accepting the UK’s suggestions for compromise. Barnier also commented that Irish issue still remains and that EU proposal on Northern Ireland is an insurance policy. Furthermore, Barnier stated the October EU leaders meeting will be the "moment of truth" and we will see whether an EU agreement is within reach. (Newswires)

In his column in the Telegraph, Jacob Rees-Mogg stated “we have one chance to get Brexit right and ridding ourselves of Chequers will let us take it”. (Telegraph)

BoE's Vlieghe said UK pay growth is increasing quite slowly and several indicators suggest low unemployment is making it difficult for employers to find or retain staff. (Newcastle Chronicle)

Italian Deputy PM Di Maio has stated that Italy are to lift their deficit/GDP ratio level to 2.5%. (Newswires)


FX

In FX markets, the greenback was subdued amid range-bound trade in its major counterparts in which EUR/USD was lacklustre after having recently failed to hold above 1.1700, while GBP/USD pared the brief support from optimistic comments by PM May who stated than an exit deal is virtually agreed and that they are nearing an orderly withdrawal agreement. Elsewhere, AUD and CAD both extended on the prior day’s commodity-fuelled gains with support also seen as CNH strengthened following Premier Li comments which dismissed competitive currency weakening, while USD/JPY remained firm above 112.00 after the safe-haven outflows from the JPY and with the BoJ policy announcement a non-event.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mostly firmer overnight although WTI crude futures seemed content on resting on the prior day’s laurels in which prices briefly broke above USD 70/bbl after reports Saudi Arabia was comfortable with prices above USD 80/bbl. WTI crude has since pulled back from US session highs and proceed sideways during Asia hours, while the latest API inventory report also momentarily weighed as headline crude stockpiles printed a surprise build. Elsewhere, gold just about reclaimed the USD 1200/oz amid a subdued greenback and copper extended on gains amid the broad heightened-risk appetite.

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (14 Sep) +1.249M vs. Exp. -2.700M (Prev. -8.636M). (Newswires)

Venezuela's Maduro said China and Venezuela will invest more than USD 5bln in the oil industry to boost production. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

South Korean President Moon and North Korean Leader Kim signed join agreement following the conclusion of official summit discussions. North Korean Leader Kim stated they will make the Korean peninsula into a place without nuclear weapons and agreed to visit Seoul. There were also comments from South Korean President Moon that both sides have agreed to eliminate threat of war in the peninsula and agreed measures for denuclearization, while he added North Korea could dismantle Yongbyun nuclear facility and can permit international inspections of dismantlement. (Newswires)

US President Trump tweeted that North Korean Leader Kim agreed to allow nuclear inspections, subject to final negotiations, and permanently dismantle a test site in the presence of international experts, while he added North and South Korea will file joint bid to host 2032 Olympics. (Newswires)


US

The US Treasury curved bear-steepened on Tuesday, with 2s10s widening by 4bps, 5s30s around 2bps wider, and 2s30s wider by around 5bps (reports of hedge funds initiating steepeners ahead of next week's FOMC). Yields on 2s and 3s saw fresh decade+ highs. Traders were happy to be sellers on Tuesday after the tariffs that the US announced on Chinese imports, and the Chinese retaliation, was at rates more benign than had been feared. Additionally, policymakers added in their statements the desire to continue constructive talks. Into the North America sessions, sellers were out in force, with rate locks on corporate new issuance and hedge fund positioning ahead of next week's FOMC no longer offset by the pension community now that the deadline for tax relief has passed, Informa reported. There was also some attention on a four-week bill sale out of the US, which sold at 2.02%. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 10+ ticks lower at 118-25+.

US President Trump said US is having a tremendous impact on China, while he added cannot let China take advantage of us. Trump also noted they may make a deal at some point and that he is always open to talk with China but warned of more tariffs if China retaliates on agricultural industry, while he also commented that a trade deal with South Korea is ready to be signed. (Newswires)

US Senate passed stop-gap funding bill to keep the government open through early December and avert a shutdown. (Newswires)

PREVIEW: Bank of Japan expected to keep policy unchanged today following the more flexible approach announced at the prior meeting
content:
The Bank of Japan will conclude its 2-day policy meeting on Wednesday in which expectations are one-sided for the central bank keep its policy settings unchanged with the bank rate to be maintained at -0.1% and long-term yield target held at around 0.0%.

The consensus for the BoJ to remain on hold comes after the July meeting where the BoJ maintained its interest rate and yield target but announced more flexibility and adopted forward guidance on rates which it said will be maintained at very low levels for an extended period. The BoJ also announced it would permit upward and downward moves in 10yr yields but will buy JGBs promptly and appropriately in the event of a rapid increase in yields, while it lowered the balance of reserves for which NIRP is applied and adjusted its ETF purchases for greater Topix and reduced Nikkei/JPX inclusions. Therefore, considering that the BoJ just recently conducted the tweaks at its last meeting, which was aimed at ensuring the sustainability of its ultra-loose policy, it is highly unlikely for the central bank to announce further adjustments so soon.

The recent key data releases have been mixed which favours a wait-and-see approach with headline National CPI (0.9% vs. Exp. 1.0%, Prev. 0.7%) and Core CPI (0.8% vs. Exp. 0.9%, Prev. 0.8%) both softer than expected and below the halfway point to the BoJ’s target which suggests BoJ are nowhere near to exiting loose policy. In addition, a firm upward revision in Q2 Annualised GDP to 3.0% vs. Exp. 2.6% (Prev. 1.9%) also points to a lack of urgency for further stimulus.

In terms of the BoJ rhetoric, BoJ Governor Kuroda commented shortly after the last meeting that he sees no need for additional easing for now and that forward guidance means to keep rates extremely low for an extended period of time. Kuroda further added that he expects factors that delayed an increase in inflation to dissipate in the future and that momentum towards 2% inflation is firmly in place.

Conversely, not all are impressed as board member and notorious dovish dissenter Kataoka stated he anticipates little chances for Japan's economy momentum to reach the price target being heightened under the current framework and that the BoJ didn't need to allow more flexibility in long-term yields when it was reducing price forecasts. Furthermore, Kataoka commented that BoJ's new forward guidance only states the obvious and that permitting long-term yields to rise could delay reaching price target, while he proposed that the BoJ should expand stimulus to achieve price target quicker instead of taking measures to prolong the period of easy policy.

As usual, there is no exact scheduled time for the policy announcement which tends to be any time after the start of the Tokyo lunch break at 0330BST/2130CDT/1030HKT, while focus will also be on the statement and the composition of votes which was previously 7-2 for YCC.

subject: South Korea and North Korea are expected to sign a military agreement on reducing tensions
ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Markets continue to shrug-off the well-telegraphed and lower than feared tit-for-tat tariffs
content:
Asia equity markets trade mostly positive following the gains in US as global markets take the well-telegraphed and lower than feared tit-for-tat tariffs between US and China in their stride. ASX 200 (+0.4%) is positive with miners and energy names outperforming following gains in copper and US crude oil in which the latter briefly rose above USD 70/bbl, while Nikkei 225 (+1.3%) outperforms on a weaker JPY and better than expected trade data. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) are kept somewhat indecisive by the uncertainty from the escalation of trade tensions and with the PBoC also slowing down on its liquidity efforts.

In FX markets, the greenback is relatively unchanged amid indecisive trade in its major counterparts with EUR/USD lacklustre after having recently failed to hold above 1.1700 and with GBP/USD paring the brief support from optimistic comments by PM May who stated than an exit deal is virtually agreed and are nearing an orderly Brexit withdrawal agreement. Elsewhere, AUD and CAD both hold on to most of the prior day’s upside which was fuelled by gains in the commodities complex as well as strong Manufacturing Sales for Canada, while USD/JPY remains firm above 112.00 after the safe-haven outflows from the JPY and with focus shifting to the BoJ policy announcement.

10yr JGBs are lower amid the outperformance of Japanese stocks but with prices off their worst levels and participants somewhat tentative as they await the BoJ.
